claim: It's always humid in Hong Kong.

supporting.text: Hong Kong has a humid subtropical climate, characterized by high humidity levels throughout most of the year, especially during the summer months.

attacks.text: Hong Kong has a humid subtropical climate, characterized by high humidity levels throughout most of the year, especially during the summer months.
Hong Kong experiences lower humidity levels during the winter months, particularly in December and January, due to the influence of the northeast monsoon.
Even during winter, the humidity in Hong Kong rarely drops below 60%, which is still considered relatively high compared to many other regions.
Urban areas in Hong Kong, such as Central and Mong Kok, often have lower humidity due to the urban heat island effect and reduced vegetation.
The urban heat island effect primarily affects temperature, not humidity, and Hong Kong's coastal location ensures high humidity even in urban areas.

supporting.text: The proximity of Hong Kong to the South China Sea contributes to persistent moisture in the air, leading to frequent high humidity.

attacks.text: The proximity of Hong Kong to the South China Sea contributes to persistent moisture in the air, leading to frequent high humidity.
Hong Kong experiences dry seasons (e.g., winter) where humidity levels drop significantly, contradicting the 'always humid' claim.
Even during dry seasons, the coastal location and urban heat island effect in Hong Kong maintain above-average humidity compared to inland areas.
Modern air conditioning systems in Hong Kong buildings actively reduce indoor humidity, creating non-humid environments despite outdoor conditions.
Climate change has increased variability in Hong Kong's humidity patterns, making persistent humidity less predictable.

supporting.text: During the winter months, Hong Kong experiences lower humidity levels due to the influence of dry northerly winds from mainland China.

attacks.text: During the winter months, Hong Kong experiences lower humidity levels due to the influence of dry northerly winds from mainland China.
Hong Kong's proximity to the South China Sea ensures year-round high humidity, even during winter.
Historical weather data shows that winter humidity in Hong Kong rarely drops below 60%, which is still considered humid.
The dry northerly winds are intermittent and do not significantly reduce humidity for most of the winter season.
Local microclimates in urban areas of Hong Kong can trap moisture, counteracting the effects of northerly winds.

supporting.text: Air conditioning and ventilation systems in urban areas of Hong Kong can reduce perceived humidity indoors, making it not 'always' humid in all environments.

attacks.text: Air conditioning and ventilation systems in urban areas of Hong Kong can reduce perceived humidity indoors, making it not 'always' humid in all environments.
Hong Kong's subtropical climate ensures high humidity levels outdoors year-round, regardless of indoor conditions.
Indoor humidity control is temporary and localized, not representative of Hong Kong's overall climate.
Many residential areas in Hong Kong lack advanced air conditioning, maintaining high humidity indoors as well.

supporting.text: The annual average relative humidity in Hong Kong is around 77-80%, indicating that high humidity is a dominant feature of its climate.

attacks.text: The annual average relative humidity in Hong Kong is around 77-80%, indicating that high humidity is a dominant feature of its climate.
While the average humidity is high, there are dry seasons (e.g., winter) when humidity drops significantly below the annual average.
Even in winter, the humidity in Hong Kong rarely drops below 60%, which is still considered relatively high compared to many other regions.
Other cities like Singapore or Bangkok have higher average humidity levels, making Hong Kong's humidity less extreme in comparison.
Regional comparisons do not negate the fact that Hong Kong's humidity is consistently high by global standards.

supporting.text: Occasional cold fronts in winter can bring drier air, temporarily reducing humidity levels below the annual average.

attacks.text: Occasional cold fronts in winter can bring drier air, temporarily reducing humidity levels below the annual average.
Hong Kong's subtropical climate ensures high humidity levels persist for the majority of the year.
Even during cold fronts, humidity levels in Hong Kong rarely drop below 60%, which is still considered humid by most standards.
The annual average relative humidity in Hong Kong is around 77%, supporting the claim that it is generally always humid.
